Mentoring

Last updated on November 27, 2022

As of June 2022, I'm taking a break from mentoring.

I reserve a portion of my time to remotely mentor designers and product managers. I do this because I find gratification in helping others navigate paths with which I‚Äôm familiar. An added bonus is that it helps me keep a pulse on how the tech industry is developing. I‚Äôve been doing this since around 2012. When I‚Äôm not taking a break from mentoring, you may schedule time with me via ADPList.

Me as a mentor

Here‚Äôs a short overview of who you‚Äôll be speaking with:

  • I have 15 years of experience making digital products
  • I‚Äôm a self-taught designer
  • I overcome imposter syndrome every day
  • My academic background is in cultural analysis and theology
  • I organize product teams with a focus on design
  • I like to push mentees just outside of their comfort zone

Where I can help

  • User advocacy: I can help you navigate office politics and stakeholder management as you work to be a calm, sincere, not-to-be-messed-with voice for the people who are not in the room.
  • Interdisciplinary collaboration: By letting you focus on individuals over processes, I can help you learn new ways of communicating in a timely and effective way inside and outside of your team.
  • Inclusivity and diversity: as a queer person of color with a background in facilitation, I can give you tools to be a colleague who makes people feel belonging, professionally and socially.
  • DesignOps and ResearchOps: I can help you explore how a more strategic way of looking at operations can benefit the work you do and the result your team produces.
  • Product strategy: Separating the buzzwords from the best practices, I can help you get started in or further enhance your strategic thinking, and the tools you use to communicate about it.

Why I mentor

These days, you can find me on ADPList, but my efforts originated on my /mentoring page, following Diana Kimball Berlin, originator of a distributed mentoring movement:

Every major step forward in my life so far has been inspired and encouraged by the mentors I‚Äôve been fortunate enough to have. I believe that hopes, dreams, and advice are best shared in ongoing, personal relationships, and it‚Äôs important to me to make myself available as a mentor to others.‚Äù

‚Äî Diana on her original /mentoring page

    I reserve a portion of my time to remotely mentor designers and researchers

Zinzy Waleson Geene (she/ they) is a researcher, designer, and queer facilitator from Amsterdam. She's interested in humanities and behavioral sciences, yoga practice, and amateur cooking. She engages in mellow cultural and critical analysis, linking and tinkering on her personal website, zinzy.website.
